title: Re-analysis of the Food Safety Plan
description: Requirements for periodic re-analysis of the Food Safety Plan including triennial review schedule, change management triggers, and documentation of re-analysis activities

requirements.question: Is there documented evidence that there is a re-analysis of the Food Safety Plan at least once every 3 years and when significant changes are made?

capaInject: Implement immediate corrective actions when triennial re-analysis deadlines are missed requiring accelerated review and documentation
Establish procedures for triggering Food Safety Plan re-analysis when significant process, equipment, or ingredient changes occur
Develop action plans when re-analysis identifies new hazards or inadequate existing controls requiring preventive control modifications
Create preventive measures including change management systems to ensure all significant changes prompt timely Food Safety Plan re-analysis
Implement verification procedures confirming PCQI conducts comprehensive re-analysis addressing all elements of the Food Safety Plan
traceabilityInject: Maintain re-analysis schedule documentation showing triennial review dates, responsible PCQI, and completion status tracking
Keep change management records documenting significant changes that trigger Food Safety Plan re-analysis requirements
Retain re-analysis reports showing comprehensive review of hazard analysis, preventive controls, monitoring, and verification procedures
Document modifications made to Food Safety Plan following re-analysis including rationale, PCQI approval, and implementation dates
Archive continuous improvement records showing how re-analysis findings drive enhanced food safety controls and system effectiveness
micro_inject: Failure to conduct triennial re-analysis allows outdated preventive controls that no longer address current Listeria monocytogenes contamination patterns
Missing re-analysis after significant changes permits introduction of new cross-contamination pathways for Salmonella from modified equipment
Inadequate re-analysis fails to recognize emerging pathogen threats including antibiotic-resistant bacteria requiring enhanced control measures
Delayed re-analysis after ingredient changes misses new hazards such as Clostridium botulinum risk in reformulated low-acid products
Lack of systematic change management results in preventive controls that fail to control E. coli O157:H7 introduced through new raw material sources
